113421 S2468-8231(23)00504-7 10.1016/j.mcat.2023.113421 Fig. 1 (a) The configuration of xh-BN/Cu catalysts; (b) The change trend of vdW interaction between h-BN coating and Cu with the increasing of spatial dimension in the xh-BN/Cu catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Reaction network of CH x (x=1-3), CH3OH and C-C bond production from syngas over Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Energies against time during AIMD simulations for the (a) 3.0h-BN/Cu, (b) 3.5h-BN/Cu, (c) 4.0h-BN/Cu, (d) 4.5h-BN/Cu, (e) 5.0h-BN/Cu, (f) 5.5h-BN/Cu, (g) 6.0h-BN/Cu, (h) 6.5h-BN/Cu, (i) 8.0h-BN/Cu and (j) Cu catalysts; the top views of catalyst structure in last snapshot are presented. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Free energy profile of CO initial activation over (a) Cu, (b) 3.0h-BN/Cu, (c) 3.5h-BN/Cu, (d) 4.0h-BN/Cu, (e) 4.5h-BN/Cu, (f) 5.0h-BN/Cu, (g) 5.5h-BN/Cu, (h) 6.0h-BN/Cu, (i) 6.5h-BN/Cu and (j) 8.0h-BN/Cu catalysts, the corresponding structures are presented in Fig. S8. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) The overall barrier at 523 K (kJ·mol−1) for the most favored path of CH x (x=1-3) and CH3OH production from syngas over Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts; (b) The rate (s−1) of CH x (x=1-3) and CH3OH production from syngas at 523 K over Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) The relationship of E con(CO) with the activity of CO hydrogenation to CHO over Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts; (b) The relationship of E con(CH2OH) with the rate of primary CH x (x=2,3) monomer and CH3OH production over 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 The activation free energy at 523 K (kJ·mol−1) of the reactions related to CH2 intermediate to produce C1 and C2 species over (a) 3.0h-BN/Cu, (b) 3.5h-BN/Cu, (c) 4.0h-BN/Cu and (d) 4.5h-BN/Cu catalysts, the corresponding structures are presented in Fig. S28. Improving catalytic performance of syngas conversion to form C2 oxygenates on the Cu-based catalyst is still a challenge. Here, 2D h-BN material covered Cu confined catalysts (xh-BN/Cu) with different spatial dimensions are rationally designed to unravel the function of spatial dimension in tuning the activity and selectivity of C2 oxygenates. The results show that the spatial dimension caused by h-BN coating in the h-BN/Cu catalyst can alter the dominant existence form of CH x (x=1-3) monomer and the corresponding activity and selectivity, in which the confinement effect arisen from h-BN coating with different spatial dimensions is confirmed to be the determined factor instead of the electronic effect. The screened 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst has outstanding catalytic performance toward the production of dominant CH x (x=1-3) monomer and C2 oxygenates. The finding provides the new design principle to rationally construct 2D material covered metal confined catalysts by adjusting the confined spatial dimension to improve catalytic performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Syngas C2 oxygenates Cu catalyst Confined space Catalytic performance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, two-dimension (2D) material covered metal confined catalysts have been widely applied to improve the catalytic performance of metal catalyst due to the distinctive confined space caused by 2D material [1–5]. 2D materials such as the hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) and graphene covered metal confined catalysts have been prepared by surface deposition method [6–8], such as the monolayer h-BN covered Ni(111) surface was successfully synthesized using B3N3H6 precursor [6]; h-BN covered Si-doped Cu catalyst was synthesized using chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [7]. Pristine graphene covered Ni(111) catalyst was prepared by low-pressure CVD [8]. However, compared with graphene, h-BN with the stronger covalent bonds and the greater band gap (5.97 eV) exhibited more excellent chemical stability, chemical inertness, and higher fracture toughness [9–11]. Specifically, h-BN can be stable up to 1274 K in air, while the corresponding temperature is about 874 K for graphene, suggesting that h-BN is more stable, so h-BN is widely used as the coating to construct the confined catalysts [12,13]. Zhang et al. [14] proposed that Cu/h-BN could substantially strengthen the adsorption capacity of dibenzothiophene and exhibit the enhanced the adsorption desulfurization (ADS) owing to the π-π interaction between the h-BN and dibenzothiophene. Ran et al. [15] also found that M/h-BN (M=Ga, In and Tl) catalyst performed considerably enhanced adsorption capacity for thiophenic compounds (THs), which is attributed to the π-π interaction between the h-BN and THs via the S−M bonds. Importantly, extensive studies have presented the influence of confinement effect arisen from 2D material coating to show excellent catalytic performance [16–18], for example, C2 oxygenates generation from syngas on the carbon nanotubes covered Rh catalyst showed that carbon nanotubes improve the dispersion of Rh, which promoted CO hydrogenation and enhanced C2 oxygenates selectivity in comparison with Rh catalyst without carbon nanotubes covered [19]. The ability of CO conversion on the graphene covered Fe catalyst was stronger by 1.5 times than that on the outside Fe catalyst, and the confined Fe catalyst is preferable for the generation of long chain hydrocarbons in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction [20]. The prepared BN/Ni0.2Cu0.8 catalyst could keep excellent stability and enhanced CO2 selectivity in methanol steam reforming [21]. The ability of CH4 and CO2 activation was greatly improved on the h-BN/(Ni, Mg)Al2O4 catalyst, which effectively inhibited sintering and showed high stability in methane dry reforming for 20 h [22]. To date, the main problem involved in C2 oxygenates generation via syngas (CO and H2) conversion is low yield and selectivity, although it is a strongly exothermic reaction [23–25]. Rh-based catalysts are extensively applied owing to the easy generation of C2 oxygenates from syngas [26,27]; however, the low CO conversion rate and high price is unfavorable for Rh industrial application. Furthermore, the low-price Cu-based catalyst performed high CO conversion rate [28,29], while the easy methanol production reduced C2 oxygenates selectivity. Usually, the generally accepted mechanism for converting syngas to produce C2 oxygenates on the Cu-based catalysts contains two vital steps [30,31], one is the generation of key intermediate CH x (x=1-3) [32,33], in which methanol production needs to be suppressed aiming at enhancing the productivity of the intermediate CH x . The other is the production of C2 oxygenate precursor CH x C(H)O via the undissociated CO/CHO insertion into CH x , followed by its continuous hydrogenation to form C2 oxygenates, meanwhile, methane from the hydrogenation of CH x or C2 hydrocarbons from CH x coupling reduce C2 oxygenate selectivity. To realize outstanding catalytic performance toward C2 oxygenates, it is crucial to efficiently promote the production of CH x and achieve the C-C bond formation, meanwhile, the formation of by-products methane, methanol and C2 hydrocarbons should be also greatly inhibited. Until now, it is still lacking clear understandings about whether the confined space formed in the h-BN coating covered Cu (h-BN/Cu) catalysts can exhibit outstanding catalytic performance for syngas transformation to form the key CH x (x=1-3) intermediate. Moreover, the intrinsic function of spatial dimension caused by h-BN coating in tuning catalytic performance of converting syngas to C2 oxygenates on Cu catalyst remains unknown. In this work, to clarify above issues, the 2D h-BN material covered Cu confined catalysts (xh-BN/Cu) with different spatial dimensions of x=3.0, 3.5, 4.0, 4.5, 5.0, 5.5, 6.0, 6.5 and 8.0 Å are rationally designed. The underlying mechanism of converting syngas to C2 oxygenates in different spatial dimensions of h-BN/Cu catalysts are investigated via performing an integrated method of density functional theory (DFT) calculations, microkinetic modeling, and ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations. Furthermore, the determined factor leading to the change of catalytic performance are elucidated by fully analyzing the electronic and geometrical properties such as density of states, work function, charge distribution, and confinement energy caused by 2D h-BN material. The results are expected to give out a deep insight into confinement effect caused by 2D h-BN material in the h-BN/Cu catalysts and offer valuable structure information to rationally design metal confined catalyst using 2D material to promote C2 oxygenates generation from syngas. 2 Computational Details 2.1 Calculation methods All theoretical calculations are completed by utilizing Dmol3 code in the Materials Studio 8.0. The electronic exchange-correlation functions [34] were treated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional with generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [35]. The effective core potential (ECP) was performed toward the inner electron of Cu atoms [36]. The double-valued basis plus polarization (DNP) was performed to treat the valence electron wave function [37]. The smearing of 0.005 Ha was adopted. A k-point grid of Brillouin-zone was set to 3 × 3 × 1 [38]. The convergence criterion of 1.0 × 10−5 Ha was set to treat the self-consistent field. The convergence criterion of force, displacement and energy during geometry optimization were chosen as 0.004 Ha/Å, 0.005 Å and 2.0 × 10−5 Ha, respectively. The Grimme method for dispersion corrections (DFT-D2) has been adopted to describe the van der Waals (vdW) interaction during the geometry optimization of the catalyst without or with species adsorption [39–41], it is well known that the DFT-D2 correction could overestimate the dispersion interaction at the metal-molecule interface, this behavior is mainly attributed to that the DFT-D2 correction is not explicitly parameterized for each d-element [39]. However, considering the computational efficiency and the widespread availability on almost all the DFT codes (such as Dmol3), DFT-D2 correction has been widely used in the extensive catalytic reactions [40,41]. The Complete LST/QST [42,43] method widely used in the previous studies [44,45] was employed to locate transition state of elementary reaction. 2.2 Models of 2D h-BN material covered Cu confined catalysts 2D material covered metal confined catalysts provide a satisfactory confined space for the reaction to perform excellent catalytic performance [46], especially, the catalytic performance toward targeted reaction can be tuned via changing spatial dimension [47,48]. DFT studies by Zhao et al. [49] studied the catalytic performance of methane production from syngas on the dual-site transition metals confined catalyst with different spatial dimension, and the optimal spatial dimension is selected by calculating the barriers of CO dissociation and its subsequent hydrogenation toward methane, indicating that the optimal spatial dimension is 4.6 Å for Ag, Cu and Pd. Zhang et al. [50] also fully studied that the effect of the spatial dimensions between the Rh surface and h-BN coating with N single vacancy (N-SV) or B single vacancy (B-SV) on CO activation, in which the spatial dimension of 3.5 Å between the h-BN coating with B-SV or N-SV and Rh(111) greatly promotes CO dissociation compared with other spatial dimension. Thus, different spatial dimension in the h-BN/Cu catalysts can be realized via altering the distances from h-BN coating to Cu surface. Meanwhile, previous studies showed that species intercalation into the confined space induced by h-BN coating causes the change of spatial dimension, namely, the spatial dimension could be altered with the size change of adsorbed species during the catalytic reaction. For example, the experiment and DFT studies by Corso et al. [51] found that the spatial dimension between the h-BN coating and Rh surface increases from 2.9 to 3.4 Å after the intercalation of 1 ML H atoms. Fu et al. [52] studied acetylene hydrogenation over graphene/Pt catalyst, indicating that the intercalation of C2H2, C2H4 and C2H6 makes the average distance between graphene coating and Pd(111) surface increase to 3.55, 3.66, and 5.04 Å from 3.20 Å, respectively; and the maximum difference in the vertical coordinates of the carbon atoms toward the undulation of graphene coating becomes 1.08, 1.27, and 0.97 Å, respectively. Moreover, as shown in Fig. S1, the spatial dimension of 3.5, 4.0, 4.5, 5.0 and 5.5 Å cannot be realized when h-BN coating is relaxed. Thus, in this study, to investigate the role of specific spatial dimension caused by h-BN coating in tuning catalytic performance of syngas conversion to C2 oxygenates over Cu catalyst, the adsorbates and the upper two layers of Cu(111) surface are relaxed during the calculation, while the h-BN coating and the bottom layer Cu are fixed to realize the specific spatial dimension during the catalytic reaction. The mainly exposed and the most stable (111) surface with three-layer p(3 × 3) supercell is adopted to model Cu catalyst [24]. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. S2, the lattice parameter of 2D h-BN is a=b=7.603 Å. The spatial dimension in the xh-BN/Cu catalysts is set to x=3.0, 3.5, 4.0, 4.5, 5.0, 5.5, 6.0, 6.5 and 8.0 Å, as shown in Fig. 1 a, which is denoted as 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu, 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu and 8.0h-BN/Cu, respectively. The spatial dimension in the h-BN/Cu catalysts is further verified to enough accommodate the reactant and target product in C2 oxygenates production from syngas. The vdW interaction (E vdW) between h-BN coating and Cu(111) in the h-BN/Cu catalysts is calculated by the following equation [53]: E vdW = E h − BN / Cu − E Cu − E h − BN Where E h-BN/Cu, E h-BN and E Cu correspond to the total energies of h-BN/Cu catalyst, h-BN coating, and Cu(111), respectively. Moreover, the energies of h-BN/Cu, h-BN coating and Cu surface are obtained via considering DFT-D2 correction. See Fig. 1b, as the h-BN coating approaches Cu catalyst, the vdW interaction changes from the attraction interaction to the repulsion interaction. Interestingly, when the spatial dimension is greater than 8.0 Å, the vdW interaction becomes stable and constant. It is noted that when the spatial dimension of h-BN/Cu catalyst is 3.0 Å, the attraction interaction is the biggest, 3.0h-BN/Cu is the most stable. Furthermore, when the spatial dimension between h-BN and Cu is greater than 8.0 Å, the effect of spatial dimension on CO molecule is negligible (Table S1). Thus, the spatial dimension between h-BN and Cu from 3.0 to 8.0 Å is considered in this study, in which the vdW interaction in the 7.0h-BN/Cu (-1.44 kJ·mol−1) and 7.5h-BN/Cu (-1.34 kJ·mol−1) catalysts are similar with that in the 8.0h-BN/Cu (-1.30 kJ·mol−1), namely, the confinement effect induced by h-BN coating is similar in the 7.0h-BN/Cu, 7.5h-BN/Cu and 8.0h-BN/Cu. Thus, the spatial dimension of 7.0 and 7.5 Å are not considered, while the larger spatial dimension of 8.0 Å is fully analyzed. 3 Results and discussions The reaction and activation free energies at 523 K of the elementary step involved in syngas conversion to produce CH x (x=1-3) and CH3OH species over 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu, 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts are listed in Table S3. Meanwhile, the possible reaction paths are mapped out in Fig. 2 . 3.1 The stability of h-BN/Cu catalysts covered by 2D h-BN material The thermal stability of h-BN/Cu catalyst is estimated by utilizing AIMD simulations, since both CH x (x=1-3) and CH3OH generation from syngas often takes place at 500-623 K [25,54,55], the NVT (T=523 K) ensemble was performed to realize the equilibrium states of h-BN/Cu catalysts [56,57]. Nose-Hoover thermostat was selected for the NVT AIMD simulations [58,59]. Only the gamma point of Brillouin zone without the consideration of symmetry is sampled in AIMD simulations performed at 523 K for 10 ps with time step of 1 fs [60–62]. As presented in Fig. 3 , the energy fluctuations with time evolution oscillates near the equilibrium state, and no obvious surface reconstruction occurs in the Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts during AIMD simulations at 523 K, it is inferred that Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts have excellent thermal stability. Thus, h-BN/Cu could provide the stable reaction space for syngas conversion. In addition, the screened 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst performs excellent catalytic performance toward syngas transformation to C2 oxygenates, AIMD simulations performed at 523 K lasted for 40 ps with time step of 1 fs, as shown in Fig. S5, the energy fluctuations remains the oscillates near the equilibrium state over time, and the catalyst surface did not have obvious change in 40 ps, namely, 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst could perform excellent stability. 3.2 The possibility of the reactant diffusion into the confined space Previously experimental studies showed that the small molecules diffusion into the confined space in 2D material covered metal catalyst follows two ways: one is that the molecule diffusion into the full monolayer of 2D material must go through the defects and vacancies [63]. The other is that the island edges of 2D materials acts as the main diffusion channels for small molecules [52]. In our studies, the second diffusion way is adopted, namely, the reactants from the island edges diffuse into the centers. Moreover, the reactant diffusion into the confined space in 2D material covered metal catalysts has been fully studied in experiment, for example, CO diffusion into the confined space starts from the island edges and easily propagates to the centers over h-BN/Ru(0001) catalyst in 3 × 10−4 mbar CO at room temperature [64]. The similar situation occurs over h-BN/Pt(111) catalyst exposing to 6.7 × 10−8 mbar CO at room temperature [65]. Ng et al. [66] also proposed that CO goes through the island edges of catalyst to diffuse into the confined space of h-BN/Rh(111) catalyst at 0.2 mbar CO and 300 K, which is attributed to the weak interaction between h-BN coating and Rh(111) surface. Moreover, the interaction between h-BN coating and Cu surface in the h-BN/Cu catalyst is weaker than that between h-BN coating and Rh/Pt surface in the h-BN/Rh(Pt) catalysts [67], namely, CO easily diffuses into the confined space of h-BN/Cu catalyst in this study. 3.3 H2 adsorption and dissociation H2 adsorption and dissociation are firstly investigated over h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts, which is usually considered as a pivotal step to supply hydrogen source in CO hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. S6, over 3.0h-BN/Cu and 3.5h-BN/Cu catalysts, H2 spontaneously dissociates into the adsorbed H atoms. However, molecular adsorption H2 occurs over 4.0h-BN/Cu, 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts, as presented in Fig. S7, the dissociation barrier (kJ·mol−1) of molecular adsorption H2 follows the order of 4.0h-BN/Cu (17.2)<4.5h-BN/Cu (36.9)<5.0h-BN/Cu (60.7)<6.0h-BN/Cu (67.7)< 5.5h-BN/Cu (90.3)<Cu (91.4)<6.5h-BN/Cu (92.7)<8.0h-BN/Cu (97.8). Thus, the spatial dimension obviously affects H2 dissociation activity, especially, the 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 4.5h-BN/Cu have higher H2 dissociation activity, which could supply enough hydrogen source for hydrogenation reaction. 3.4 CO initial activation Two possible paths exist: the first is the C−O bond scission in CO to generate C+O; the second is CO hydrogenation to produce CHO/COH. See Fig. 4 a, on the Cu catalyst, CHO production is kinetically favored in comparison with COH generation and the direct dissociation of CO (93.0 vs. 206.8 and 429.1 kJ·mol−1), which agrees with the previously reported studies [24]. As presented in Figs. 4b∼4j, the similar situation also occurs on the other h-BN/Cu catalysts, the activity of CO hydrogenation to CHO (kJ·mol−1) is in sequence of 4.0h-BN/Cu (75.0)>3.0h-BN/Cu (77.5)>Cu (93.0)> 3.5h-BN/Cu (99.0)>5.5h-BN/Cu (99.4)>6.0h-BN/Cu (100.2)>8.0h-BN/Cu (101.1)> 6.5h-BN/Cu (105.7)>4.5h-BN/Cu (124.7)>5.0h-BN/Cu (151.8), namely, the spatial dimension obviously impacts the ability of CO activation due to different CO adsorption ability (kJ·mol−1) with the order of 8.0h-BN/Cu (-67.1)>6.0h-BN/Cu (-62.7)> 6.5h-BN/Cu (-61.7)>5.5h-BN/Cu (-60.9)>Cu (-57.3)>5.0h-BN/Cu (-37.9)> 4.5h-BN/Cu (26.2)>4.0h-BN/Cu (109.1)>3.5h-BN/Cu (223.0)>3.0h-BN/Cu (364.2). 3.5 The production of CH x intermediate and methanol Above results show that the main product is CHO for CO initial activation, thus, the key intermediate CH x (x=1-3) is dominantly generated via the C−O bond scission in CH x OH(x=1,2) or CH x O(x=1-3) from CHO hydrogenation. Meanwhile, in this work, the overall barrier from the reactant to the product for the considered route is defined by the energy difference between the reactant and transition state (TS) with the highest energy [68–70], in which the smaller overall barrier means the higher activity toward the product formation. The detailed descriptions for reaction network are presented in the Supplementary Material. 3.5.1 The production of CH intermediate CH could be produced via two paths: the first is CO+H→CHO→CH+O (Path 1-1); the second is CO+2H→CHO+H→CHOH→CH+OH (Path 1-2) over Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts (Figs. S9∼S21). Over 3.0h-BN/Cu and 3.5h-BN/Cu, Path 1-1 is responsible for CH generation. Over the other h-BN/Cu catalysts, CH is dominantly produced via Path 1-2. CH activity (Fig. 5 a) is closely linked with the spatial dimension, following the sequence (kJ·mol−1) of 3.0h-BN/Cu (111.6)>4.0h-BN/Cu (128.0)>3.5h-BN/Cu (138.8)>4.5h-BN/Cu (191.1)>5.0h-BN/Cu (206.4)>Cu (221.0)> 5.5h-BN/Cu (231.0)>6.5h-BN/Cu (240.0)>6.0h-BN/Cu (240.7)>8.0h-BN/Cu (253.2), namely, the 3.0h-BN/Cu catalyst performs the highest CH production activity. 3.5.2 The production of CH2 intermediate Five possible paths exist over Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts: (Path 2-1) CO + H → CHO + H → C H 2 O → C H 2 + O (Path 2-2) CO + H → CHO + H → C H 2 O + H → C H 2 OH → C H 2 + OH (Path 2-3) CO + H → CHO + H → CHOH + H → C H 2 OH → C H 2 + OH (Path 2-4) CO + H → CHO + H → CHOH → CH + OH + H → C H 2 + OH (Path 2-5) CO + H → CHO → CH + O + H → C H 2 + O CH2 production activity (kJ·mol−1) is in order of 4.0h-BN/Cu (83.1)>3.5h-BN/Cu (99.0)>3.0h-BN/Cu (111.6)>4.5h-BN/Cu (148.2)>5.0h-BN/Cu (161.3)>5.5h-BN/Cu (179.8)>Cu (187.9)>8.0h-BN/Cu (193.7)> 6.5h-BN/Cu (196.1)>6.0h-BN/Cu (196.6) (Fig. 5a), thus, 4.0h-BN/Cu is the most suitable catalyst to produce CH2. 3.5.3 The production of CH3 intermediate CH3 is produced via the following six paths. (Path 3-1) CO + H → CHO + H → C H 2 O + H → C H 3 O → C H 3 + O (Path 3-2) CO + H → CHO + H → C H 2 O + H → C H 2 OH → C H 2 + OH + H → C H 3 + OH (Path 3-3) CO + H → CHO + H → CHOH + H → C H 2 OH → C H 2 + OH + H → C H 3 + OH (Path 3-4) CO + H → CHO + H → CHOH → CH + OH + H → C H 2 + OH + H → C H 3 + OH (Path 3-5) CO + H → CHO + H → C H 2 O → C H 2 + O + H → C H 3 (Path 3-6) CO + H → CHO → CH + O + H → C H 2 + O + H → C H 3 + O CH3 production activity is affected by the spatial dimension (Fig. 5a), following the order (kJ·mol−1) of 4.0h-BN/Cu (83.1)>3.5h-BN/Cu (99.0)>3.0h-BN/Cu (111.6)> 4.5h-BN/Cu (148.2)>5.0h-BN/Cu (161.3)>5.5h-BN/Cu (179.8)>Cu (187.9)> 8.0h-BN/Cu (193.7)>6.5h-BN/Cu (196.1)>6.0h-BN/Cu (196.6), thus, the 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst performs the highest activity toward CH3 generation. Above results show that over 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu catalysts, as shown in Fig. S22a, CH serves as the precursor of CH2 or CH3 production over 3.0h-BN/Cu, in which the overall barriers of CH x (x=1-3) production are similar (111.6 kJ·mol−1). However, as shown in Fig. S22b, over 3.5h-BN/Cu, CH2 is mainly produced via CH2O direct dissociation instead of CH hydrogenation (99.0 vs. 138.8 kJ·mol−1), subsequently, CH3 is produced via the hydrogenation of the precursor CH2, and the overall barriers of CH x (x=2, 3) production are similar (99.0 kJ·mol−1). Similarly, as shown in Fig. S22c, over 4.0h-BN/Cu, CH2 is mainly produced via CH2OH direct dissociation instead of CH hydrogenation (83.1 vs. 128.0 kJ·mol−1), subsequently, CH3 is produced via the hydrogenation of the precursor CH2, and the overall barriers of CH x (x=2, 3) production are similar (83.1 kJ·mol−1). Thus, CH production activity order (kJ·mol−1) of 3.0h-BN/Cu (111.6)>4.0h-BN/Cu (128.0)> 3.5h-BN/Cu (138.8) does not follow the pattern as CH2 and CH3 production activity order (kJ·mol−1) of 4.0h-BN/Cu (83.1)>3.5h-BN/Cu (99.0)>3.0h-BN/Cu (111.6), which is attributed to that CH2 serves as the precursor of CH3 production with the same overall barrier over these three catalysts, while CH is the precursor of CH2 production over 3.0h-BN/Cu catalyst, CH is not the precursor of CH2 production over 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu. 3.5.4 The production of methanol CH3OH could be produced via the successive hydrogenation of CH2OH or CH3O intermediate, and there are three paths. (Path 4-1) CO + H → CHO + H → C H 2 O + H → C H 3 O + H → C H 3 OH (Path 4-2) CO + H → CHO + H → C H 2 O + H → C H 2 OH + H → C H 3 OH (Path 4-3) CO + H → CHO + H → CHOH + H → C H 2 OH + H → C H 3 OH Since the optimized structure shows that CH3OH initially adsorbed over Cu surfaces in the 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu catalysts easily takes place the spontaneous dissociation (see Figs. S10, S12 and S15), namely, CH3OH cannot stably exist, CH3OH production is not considered over these three h-BN/Cu catalysts. For the 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu (Table S2), CH2O desorption occurs easily, so Paths 4-1 and 4-2 are not favored to produce CH3OH. See Figs. S9∼S21, CH3OH could be produced via Path 4-3 with the activity (kJ·mol−1) of 6.5h-BN/Cu (164.2)>Cu (169.2)>6.0h-BN/Cu (177.0)>8.0h-BN/Cu (177.3)>5.5h-BN/Cu (179.8)>5.0h-BN/Cu (185.5)>4.5h-BN/Cu (186.7), thus, CH3OH production activity is also affected by the spatial dimension. 3.6 General Discussions 3.6.1 Influence of spatial dimension on CHx activity by microkinetic modeling In order to further unravel the influence of spatial dimension on the activity and selectivity of key intermediate CH x (x=1-3) generation from syngas under the realistic reaction conditions (P CO=4 atm, P H2=8 atm, T=523 K), microkinetic modeling is implemented to estimate the rate of CH x generation on the Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts [71,72] (details in the Supplementary Material), which considered the influences of the experimentally related reaction pressure, reaction temperature, as well as the coverage of the species, as listed in Tables S6 and S7. See Fig. 5b, CH production rate is higher than CH2 and CH3 production rate on the 3.0h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts, CH is the primary CH x monomer. CH2 production rate is higher than CH and CH3 production rate over 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 5.5h-BN/Cu catalysts, CH2 is the primary CH x monomer. However, CH3 production rate is higher than CH and CH2 production rate over 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu and 8.0h-BN/Cu catalysts, CH3 becomes the dominant CH x monomer. Further, the rate (s−1) of the primary CH x (x=1-3) production is 3.0h-BN/Cu (2.71)>4.0h-BN/Cu (6.48 × 10−2)>4.5h-BN/Cu (1.91 × 10−5)>3.5h-BN/Cu (8.49 × 10−8)> 5.0h-BN/Cu (2.30 × 10−8)>5.5h-BN/Cu (5.19 × 10−9)>8.0h-BN/Cu (2.12 × 10−10)>Cu (5.12 × 10−11)>6.0h-BN/Cu (1.92 × 10−11)>6.5h-BN/Cu (6.22 × 10−17), namely, 3.0h-BN/Cu catalyst presents the highest activity toward the primary CH x monomer production, which disagree with our DFT results. This situation could be attributed to the effect of species coverage. Previous studies also showed that the species coverage greatly impacts the activity and selectivity of product [73–76]. Thus, the activity of the primary CH x monomer production and its dominant existence form over Cu and h-BN/Cu catalysts strongly depend on the spatial dimension of confined space. 3.6.2 Influence of spatial dimension on CHx selectivity by microkinetic modeling CH3OH can decrease the selectivity of CH x intermediate in syngas conversion. As shown in Fig. 5b, the rate of CH3OH production over h-BN/Cu catalysts is much smaller than that on the Cu catalyst, namely, h-BN coating can effectively decrease CH3OH production activity. Among them, since CH3OH easily take place the spontaneous dissociation over 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu catalysts, these three catalysts could well inhibit methanol formation, correspondingly, CH selectivity is 99.8% on the 3.0h-BN/Cu catalyst, CH2 selectivity is 97.5% and 100% over 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu catalysts, respectively. CH3 selectivity on the 4.5h-BN/Cu catalyst is 96.4%. However, CH3OH production rate is quicker than the primary CH x (x=1-3) production rate over 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts, correspondingly, the selectivity of CH3OH is 99.6%, 100%, 100%, 100%, 100% and 100% (Table S7), respectively. Thus, it is concluded that the selectivity of CH3OH and the primary CH x (x=1-3) monomer also depends on the spatial dimension caused by h-BN coating. As mentioned above, the dominant existence form of CH x (x=1-3) monomer can be tuned by the spatial dimension in the h-BN/Cu catalyst, which dramatically decreases CH3OH production activity in comparison with Cu catalyst, however, the activity of CH3OH production is still higher than that of the primary CH x (x=1-3) monomer over 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts, which leads to high CH3OH selectivity. On the contrary, the higher activity and selectivity of the primary CH x (x=1-3) monomer production than those of CH3OH production occur over 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 4.5h-BN/Cu catalysts, which can be regarded as a good candidate with excellent catalytic performance toward CH x (x=1-3) monomer generation, namely, the spatial dimension from 3.0 to 4.5 Å is the most suitable range. 3.6.3 Influence of h-BN/Cu catalyst confinement effect caused by 2D h-BN To further unveil the underlying determined factor to affect CO activation ability and the primary CH x (x=1-3) monomer activity, the confinement effect of h-BN coating is considered, which can be quantitatively reflected by the confinement energy (E con) obtained by the following equation [53]: E con = E ads ( h − BN / Cu ) − E ads ( Cu ) Where E ads(h-BN/Cu) and E ads(Cu) represent the adsorption energy of the species over Cu catalysts with and without h-BN coating, respectively, and the greater value of E con means the stronger confinement effect arisen from h-BN coating, namely, the confinement effect of h-BN coating is closely linked with the species adsorption energy. Moreover, it is originated from the vdW interaction, specifically, the vdW interaction between the h-BN coating and Cu surface induces the strong spatial constraint for the trapped molecules, in which the attractive vdW interaction between the coating and metal surface causes the trapped molecule much closer to the coating and the change of the trapped molecule adsorption ability in the confined space [53]. Meanwhile, previous studies also showed that the vdW interaction between the 2D materials can be so strong in a nanometer scale, in which the huge pressure up to 1 GPa is built [77,78]. As shown in Table S8, E con(CO) (kJ·mol−1) is in sequence of 3.0h-BN/Cu (421.5)> 3.5h-BN/Cu (280.3)>4.0h-BN/Cu (166.4)>4.5h-BN/Cu (83.5)>5.0h-BN/Cu (19.4)> Cu (0.0)>5.5h-BN/Cu (-3.6)>6.5h-BN/Cu (-4.4)>6.0h-BN/Cu (-5.4)>8.0h-BN/Cu (-9.8), namely, the spatial dimension obviously changes the confinement effect arisen from h-BN coating. As presented in Fig. 6 a, on the 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst, h-BN coating put the moderate confinement effect on CO, leading to the highest CO activation ability, in other words, the spatial dimension of 4.0 Å is more beneficial for CO activation compared to the other larger or smaller spatial dimension. Furthermore, when the spatial dimension increases from 5.5 Å to infinity, E con(CO) changes slightly (from -9.8 to 0 kJ·mol−1), correspondingly, CO activation ability slightly changes. Thus, CO activation ability is closely linked with the confinement effect arisen from h-BN coating. Above analysis shows that the h-BN coating puts a strong confinement effect on CO, resulting in its weak adsorption ability (109.1 kJ·mol−1) over 4.0h-BN/Cu. This situation also occurs over the other confined catalysts covered by two-dimensional materials [16,53,66,79]. It is worth noting that the h-BN coating acts as a constraint boundary for CO molecule in the 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst, namely, although CO adsorption ability is weak, it can still participate into the reaction in the confined space since CO molecule cannot relax farther away from the surface sufficiently. Furthermore, H2 dissociation easily occurs to supply enough hydrogen sources for hydrogenation reaction, and CHO production is dominant path toward CO initial activation. Correspondingly, the effect of H adsorption on the adsorption energy of CO over 4.0h-BN/Cu is analyzed, the adsorption energy of CO increases from 109.1 kJ·mol−1 to 28.2 kJ·mol−1 over 4.0h-BN/Cu without or with H adsorption, namely, H atom adsorption obviously enhances adsorption ability of CO. Thus, the occurrence of CO related reaction is easy in the 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst when H atoms are adsorbed, which performs excellent catalytic performance toward C2 oxygenates in syngas conversion. On the other hand, over 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu, the optimized structures show that CH3OH initially adsorbed over Cu surfaces in the 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu easily takes place the spontaneous dissociation, suggesting that CH3OH cannot stably exist (see Figs. S10, S12 and S15), so the confinement effect arisen from h-BN coating results in the difficult occurrence of CH3OH formation and makes the 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu perform high CH x (x=1-3) selectivity. Over 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu, since CH2 hydrogenation is considered as the dominant path to produce CH3, in which CH2 is produced via the C−O bond cracking in CH2OH, moreover, the generation of CH3OH mainly occurs via the hydrogenation of CH2OH, as a result, CH2OH is the key intermediate in the generation process of primary CH x monomer and CH3OH. Thus, E con(CH2OH) is calculated over 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu. As shown in Table S8 and Fig. 6b, over 4.5h-BN/Cu, E con(CH2OH) is much bigger than that over the other catalysts (43.8 vs. -4.4, -14.8, -16.0, -9.6, -4.3 and 0 kJ·mol−1); the values of E con(CH2OH) rapidly decreased when the spatial dimension is larger than 4.5 Å, namely, the weakened confinement effect of h-BN coating promotes CH2OH hydrogenation to CH3OH rather than the C−O bond scission of CH2OH to generate CH2+OH, resulting in higher CH3OH activity than CH x production over xh-BN/Cu (x=5.0, 5.5, 6.0, 6.5 and 8.0) and Cu catalysts. Thus, h-BN coating in the 4.5h-BN/Cu catalyst puts the highest confinement effect on CH2OH to perform the higher CH3 activity and significantly inhibit CH3OH production, namely, only when the dimension was smaller than 5.0 Å, the impact of spatial dimensions on the selectivity of main products became dominant. The electronic properties of h-BN/Cu and Cu catalyst (see Supplementary Material) further confirm that the electronic effect is not the determined factor in regulating the activity of CO activation and the primary CH x (x=1-3) production, the confinement effect arisen from h-BN coating is the mainly determined factor, thus, the confinement energy E con is thought to be a significant descriptor of driving force that adjusts catalytic performance. Meanwhile, it is proposed that the higher confinement effect induced by h-BN coating in the spatial dimension from 3.0 to 4.5 Å is recognized to be the main reason for the difficult occurrence of CH3OH production, the higher confinement effect leads to the metastable state CO and CH2OH, which facilitates CO conversion to produce CH2OH, followed by its C−O bond breakage to generate CH2+OH instead of CH2OH hydrogenation to CH3OH. For example, on h-BN/Pt catalyst, the h-BN coating imposes a strong confinement effect on CO, in which CO is metastable state resulting in the easy conversion of CO to form CO2 [65,80]. DFT studies and in situ characterization [81] found that h-BN coating caused the weaker ability of O, H and OH adsorption on the h-BN/Ni catalyst compared with the bare Ni catalyst, in which the h-BN/Ni catalyst performed high activity of hydrogen oxidation reactions arise from the metastable state O, H and OH species. 3.6.4 C2 oxygenate generation over h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts Once CH x (x=1-3) intermediates are generated, C2 oxygenate precursor generation easily occurs, including CH x reacting with CO/CHO to CH x CO/CH x CHO [32,33]. Since the 5.0h-BN/Cu, 5.5h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu, 8.0h-BN/Cu and Cu catalysts prefer CH3OH generation rather than CH x (x=1-3), which cannot supply the key intermediate CH x (x=1-3), the generation of C2 oxygenate is difficult. However, CH3OH production is difficult over 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 4.5h-BN/Cu catalysts, which exhibit high CH, CH2, CH2 and CH3 selectivity, respectively. On the 3.0h-BN/Cu, see Table S3, CH hydrogenation to CH2 is more feasible among the reaction related to CH monomer, so the related reaction of CH2 to produce C1 and C2 species are considered. On 4.5h-BN/Cu, CH3 production mainly undergoes the hydrogenation of CH2, namely, CH2 serves as precursor to produce CH3. Thus, the related reactions of CH2 intermediate to produce C1 and C2 species are calculated over 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 4.5h-BN/Cu, including CH2 reacting with CO/CHO to CH2CO/CH2CHO, CH2 hydrogenation to CH3 and CH2 coupling to C2 hydrocarbons. As presented in Fig. 7 , over 3.0h-BN/Cu, the overall barrier of CH2 coupling to C2H4 is lower than that of CH2 reacting with CO/CHO to CH2CO/CH2CHO and CH2 hydrogenation to CH3 (14.6 vs. 74.3, 44.9 and 116.8 kJ·mol−1), namely, the occurrence of C2H4 production is easier than the production of CH2CO, CH2CHO and CH3. Moreover, CH4 is produced via the hydrogenation of CH3, suggesting that the production of CH4 is more difficult than C2H4 production, so the dominant product is C2H4 over 3.0h-BN/Cu. Similarly, CH4 production is also difficult to occur over 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 4.5h-BN/Cu catalysts. Over 3.5h-BN/Cu, C2 oxygenate CH2CO is the dominant product. Over 4.0h-BN/Cu, C2 oxygenate CH2CO and CH2CHO are the dominant product. Over 4.5h-BN/Cu, C2H4 is the dominant product. Above analysis show that both 3.5h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu catalysts prefer C2 oxygenate production, while both 3.0h-BN/Cu and 4.5h-BN/Cu catalysts mainly contribute to C2H4 production. The above microkinetic modeling suggests that among h-BN/Cu catalysts, the 3.0h-BN/Cu, 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 4.5h-BN/Cu catalysts could well inhibit methanol formation, correspondingly, the selectivity of the primary CH x (x=1-3) production is in sequence of 4.0h-BN/Cu (100%)>3.0h-BN/Cu (99.8%)>3.5h-BN/Cu (97.5%)>4.5h-BN/Cu (96.4%), suggesting that 4.0h-BN/Cu performs the highest primary CH x (x=1-3) selectivity. Correspondingly, the rate (s−1) of the primary CH x (x=1-3) production is in sequence of 3.0h-BN/Cu (2.71)>4.0h-BN/Cu (6.48 × 10−2)> 4.5h-BN/Cu (1.91 × 10−5)>3.5h-BN/Cu (8.49 × 10−8), in which the 3.0h-BN/Cu and 4.0h-BN/Cu catalysts present excellent activity toward the primary CH x monomer production. Considering the activity and selectivity of the dominant CH x (x=1-3) monomer and C2 oxygenates generation, 4.0h-BN/Cu is considered as the most promising catalyst toward the conversion of syngas to produce C2 oxygenates, which not only has excellent CH2 production activity and selectivity, but also prefers the occurrence of C2 oxygenate precursor CH2CO and CH2CHO production. Thus, the strong confinement effect of h-BN coating in the 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst results in the easy C−O bond breakage of CH3OH to produce CH3 and OH, which can well inhibit CH3OH formation. Meanwhile, the confinement effect of h-BN coating prefers the C−O bond breakage of CH2OH to produce the primary CH2 monomer with the small activation free energy of 26.7 kJ·mol−1. Subsequently, the undissociated CO or CHO inserts into CH x to produce C2 oxygenates CH2CHO and CH2CO, which only requires the activation free energies of 19.5 and 20.5 kJ·mol−1, respectively, namely, C2 oxygenates is dominant product over 4.0h-BN/Cu. Meanwhile, above analysis shows that the most advantageous path over 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst in syngas conversion to C2 oxygenates is CO+H→CHO+H→CH2O+H→CH2OH→CH2+OH+CO→CH2CO and CO+H→CHO+H→CH2O+H→CH2OH→CH2+OH+CHO→CH2CHO. 3.6.5 Feasibility of preparation and application for h-BN/Cu catalyst with different spatial dimension Nowadays, the spatial dimension of confined catalyst could be controlled in experiment, firstly, the CNT/M catalysts with different spatial dimension could be achieved via using different size carbon nanotubes (CNT) to cover metal catalyst or the similar CNT to cover different particle sizes of metal catalyst. Seo et al. [82] prepared CNT/CoO x catalysts with different confined space, the CoO x catalysts with the particle sizes of 3.0, 6.2, 7.4, and 9.1 nm were prepared, and then it was covered by CNTs using ultrasonication. Wang et al. [48] performed the method of convenient sonication-assisted impregnation to obtain CNT/Cu catalysts with different confined space, in which the multiwall CNTs with small diameter (inner diameter: 4-10 nm) and large diameter (inner diameter: 20-30 nm) cover Cu nanoparticles. Since the structure of h-BN nanotube (BNNTs) is similar with CNT [83], the h-BN/Cu catalysts with different spatial dimension could be achieved through above similar methods with different sizes of BNNTs covering Cu catalyst. Moreover, BNNTs with different inner diameters can be synthesized by thermal-heating chemical vapor deposition, for example, BNNTs has the inner diameter of 1-3 nm or diameters of 30-300 nm [83,84]. Silva et al. [85] used solvothermal process to prepare BNNTs/Cu catalyst. Based on above analysis, it is inferred that the preparation of h-BN/Cu catalysts with different spatial dimension could be realized in experiment, and it can be applied to the conversion of syngas to form C2 oxygenates and present better catalytic activity, selectivity, and catalyst stability. 4 Conclusions In this research, the methods of DFT calculations combining with microkinetic modeling are carried out to unravel the underlying function of spatial dimension caused by 2D h-BN material in 2D h-BN covered Cu confined catalysts (h-BN/Cu) for syngas conversion to form C2 oxygenates. The outstanding thermal stability of h-BN/Cu catalysts is confirmed using AIMD simulations. The dominant existence form of CH x (x=1-3) monomer, as well as the corresponding activity and selectivity could be tuned by changing the spatial dimension induced by h-BN coating. CH3 is found to be the dominant CH x monomer over 4.5h-BN/Cu, 5.0h-BN/Cu, 6.0h-BN/Cu, 6.5h-BN/Cu and 8.0h-BN/Cu catalysts, while it is CH on the 3.0h-BN/Cu, CH2 over 3.5h-BN/Cu, 4.0h-BN/Cu and 5.5h-BN/Cu catalysts. The electronic properties of Cu surface in the h-BN/Cu catalysts have negligible effect on CH x (x=1-3) activity and selectivity, which is not the determined factor to affect catalytic performance. The confinement effect arisen from 2D h-BN material is confirmed to be the determined factor to alter catalytic performance. Among nine kinds of h-BN/Cu catalysts, the screened 4.0h-BN/Cu is the most promising catalyst, which could present excellent catalytic performance toward the generation of the dominant CH2 monomer due to strong confinement energy arisen from h-BN coating, which significantly inhibits CH3OH production and favors CH2 production, further, C2 oxygenates production easily occurs. Thus, the spatial dimension caused by 2D material in the 2D material covered Cu confined catalysts is useful structure information to rationally design the desired Cu catalyst, which could produce C2 oxygenates to possess excellent activity and selectivity. The detailed descriptions about the methods of adsorption energy, the reactions involving in CO conversion to form CH x and CH3OH, H2 adsorption and dissociation, microkinetic modeling, d-band center, the confinement energy and C2 species production are presented. coredata.dc:description: Improving catalytic performance of syngas conversion to form C2 oxygenates on the Cu-based catalyst is still a challenge. Here, 2D h-BN material covered Cu confined catalysts (xh-BN/Cu) with different spatial dimensions are rationally designed to unravel the function of spatial dimension in tuning the activity and selectivity of C2 oxygenates. The results show that the spatial dimension caused by h-BN coating in the h-BN/Cu catalyst can alter the dominant existence form of CH x (x=1-3) monomer and the corresponding activity and selectivity, in which the confinement effect arisen from h-BN coating with different spatial dimensions is confirmed to be the determined factor instead of the electronic effect. The screened 4.0h-BN/Cu catalyst has outstanding catalytic performance toward the production of dominant CH x (x=1-3) monomer and C2 oxygenates. The finding provides the new design principle to rationally construct 2D material covered metal confined catalysts by adjusting the confined spatial dimension to improve catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: 2D h-BN material covered Cu confined catalysts: unraveling the function of spatial dimension in tuning activity and selectivity of syngas-to-C2 oxygenates
